summary: This is a status update memorandum from the DOJ Office of the Inspector General (OIG) to the Federal Bureau of Prisons (BOP) regarding the BOP's response to eight recommendations from the OIG's final report on the custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center. The OIG assesses the BOP's progress on each recommendation, finding some responses adequate and others insufficient.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased inmate whose custody and death at the Metropolitan Correctional Center is the subject of the OIG's underlying investigation and report. His case is cited as an example of policy failures.

events.title: OIG Final Report Release
events.description: The Office of the Inspector General issued its final report on the investigation and review of the BOP's custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center.

events.title: BOP Status Update Submission
events.description: The Federal Bureau of Prisons provided a status update to the OIG in response to the eight recommendations from the June 26, 2023, report.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, New York
keyFacts: The OIG's investigation found a lack of a contingency plan to assign Epstein a new cellmate after his previous cellmate was transferred, which increased the likelihood he was housed alone at the time of his death.
The BOP's response to Recommendation 2 (ensuring continuity of cellmate assignment) was deemed non-responsive by the OIG, as it did not address the need for a contingency plan.
The BOP's response to Recommendation 7 (evaluating cell search procedures) was also deemed non-responsive, as it only mentioned discussing existing policies, not evaluating and improving them.

The document outlines eight specific policy and procedural recommendations for the BOP stemming from the Epstein case, focusing on suicide watch protocols, inmate accountability, staffing, and security systems.
